message: Somebody else should run this.|vs: mouth|
I'm sick of being the one to sort of go through and say, "Well, what do you think about this?"|vs: laugh|
Should we take turns? You want me to run it today?|
Yeah. Why don't you run it today? O_K.|vs: laugh|
Let's see, maybe we should just get a list of items -|vs: mouth|
things that we should talk about.|
I guess there's the usual  updates, everybody going around and saying,|
uh, you know, what they're working on, the things that happened the last week.|
But aside from that is there anything in particular that anybody wants to bring up|
No? O_K. So why don't we just around and people can give updates. Uh, do you want to start, Stephane?|
Alright. Um. Well, the first thing maybe is that the p- Eurospeech paper is, uh, accepted.|vs: mouth|
This is - what - what do you, uh - what's in the paper there?|
So it's the paper that describe basically the, um,|
system that were proposed for the  Aurora.|
The one that we s- we submitted the last round?|
Um - Yeah. So and the, fff  comments seems - from the reviewer are good. So.|vs: breath-laugh|
Where - where's it gonna be this year?|
It's, uh, Aalborg in Denmark. And it's, yeah,|
Yeah. Then, uh, whhh  well, I've been working on - on t- mainly on on-line normalization this week.|
Uh, I've been trying different - slightly - slightly different approaches.|
Um, the first thing is trying to play a little bit again with the, um, time constant.|vs: mouth|
Uh, second thing is, uh, the training of, uh, on-line normalization with two different means,|
one mean for the silence and one for the speech.|
and so I have two recursions which are controlled by the, um, probability of the voice activity detector.|vs: mouth|
This actually don't s- doesn't seem to help,|vs: mouth|vs: breath|
But - well, both  on-line normalization approach seems equivalent.|
Are the means pretty different  for the two?|
Yeah. They can be very different. Yeah. Mm-hmm.|
So do you maybe make errors in different places? Different kinds of errors?|vs: mouth|
I didn't look, uh, more closely. Um. It might be, yeah. Mm-hmm.|vs: mouth|
Well, eh, there is one thing that we can observe, is that the mean are more different for -|vs: mouth|
for C_zero and C_one than for the other coefficients.|
And - Yeah, it - the C_one is -|
There are strange - strange thing happening with C_one, is that|
when you have different kind of noises, the mean for the - the silence portion is - can be|
So when you look at the trajectory of C_one, it's - has a strange shape and|vs: mouth|
I was expecting th- the s- that these two mean helps, especially because of the - the strange|
uh, which can - like, yo- you can have,|
a trajectory for the speech and then when you are in the silence it goes somewhere, but if the noise is different it goes somewhere else.|
So which would mean that if we estimate the mean based on all the signal, even though we have|
frame dropping, but we don't frame ev- uh, drop  everything,  but -|
uh, this can - hurts the estimation of the mean for speech, and -|
Mmm.   But I still have to investigate further, I think.|
Um, a third thing is, um,|
t- having a fixed time constant,|
I try to have a time constant that's smaller at the beginning of the utterances|
to adapt more quickly to the r- something that's closer to the right mean.|
Yeah. And then this time constant increases and I have a threshold that -|
well, if it's higher than a certain threshold, I keep it to this threshold to still,|
uh, adapt, um, the mean when -|
if the utterance is, uh, long enough to - to continue to adapt after, like, one second or -|vs: clears throat|
Uh, well, this doesn't help neither,  but this doesn't hurt. So, well.|vs: laugh|
Wasn't there some experiment you were gonna try where you did something differently for each,|
um,  uh - I don't know whether it was each|vs: mouth|
mel band or each, uh, um, F_F_T bin or someth- There was something you were gonna -|
some parameter you were gonna vary depending on the frequency.|
I don't know if that was -|
I don't know. No. u- Maybe it's this - this idea of having different  on-line normalization,|
um, tunings for the different M_F_C_C's.|
Yeah. I - I thought, Morgan, you brought it up a couple meetings ago. And then it was something about,|
uh, some- and then somebody said "yeah, it does seem like, you know, C_zero is|
the one that's, you know, the major one" or, uh, s- I can't remember exactly what it was now.|
S- um, it's very important to normalize C_zero and  much less to normalize the other coefficients. And, um,|
actu- uh, well, at least with the current on-line normalization scheme. And|
kind of know that normalizing C_one doesn't help with the current scheme. And -|
I was thinking that the - the - the reason is maybe because of these funny things that happen between speech and silence which have different means.|
But maybe it's not so -  so easy to -|vs: outbreath|
I- I really would like to suggest looking, um,|
a little bit at the kinds of errors. I know you can get lost in that and go forever and not see too much, but -|
just seeing that each of these things didn't make things better may not|
be enough. It may be that they're making them better in some ways and worse in others, or increasing insertions and decreasing deletions, or -|
you know, helping with noisy case but hurting in quiet case. And if you  saw  that then maybe you - it would -|
something would occur to you of how to deal with that.|vs: mouth|
So that's it, I think, for the on-line normalization.|
Yeah. I've been playing a little bit with|
as a first experiment, I think I-|
Yeah. Well, what I did is t- is to take,|
no, the maximum energy of s- each utterance and then put a threshold -|
Well, this for each mel band.|
Then put a threshold that's fifteen D_B below -|
well, uh, a couple of D_B below this maximum, and -|
Actually it was not a threshold, it was just adding noise.|
So I was adding a white noise energy,|
uh, that's fifteen D_B below the maximum energy of the utterance.|vs: breath|
Yeah. When we look at - at the, um, M_F_C_C that result from this, they are  a lot more smoother.|
when we compare, like, a channel zero and channel one utterance -|
um, so a clean and, uh, the same noisy utterance -|
well, there is almost no difference between the cepstral coefficients of the two.|
And - Yeah. And the result that we have in term of speech recognition, actually it's not - it's not  worse,|
but it's, um, kind of surprising that it's not worse because|
basically you add noise that's fifteen D_B - just fifteen D_B below  the maximum energy. And|
So why does that m-  smooth things out? I don't - I don't understand that.|
Well, there's less difference. Right? Cuz it's -|
This - the portion that are more silent, as you add a white noise that are - has a very high energy, it whitens everything and -|
and the high-energy portion of the speech|
don't get much affected anyway by the other noise. And as the noise you add is the same is -  the shape, it's also the same.|
So they have - the trajectory are very, very similar. And - and -|
So, I mean, again, if you trained in one kind of noise and tested in the same kind of noise, you'd -|vs: mouth|
you know, given enough training data you don't do b- do badly.|vs: breath|
The reason that we d- that we have the  problems  we have is because  it's different in training and test. Even if|
the general  kind  is the same, the exact instances are different. And - and|vs: breath|
so when you  whiten  it, then it's like you - the - the only noise -|
to - to first order, the only th- noise that you  have  is white noise and you've added the same thing to training and test. So it's,|
So would that  be similar to, like, doing the smoothing, then, over time or - ?|
Well, it's a  kind  of smoothing, but -|
I think it's - I think it's different. It's -|
it's something that - yeah, that affects more or less the silence portions because -|
Well, anyway, the sp- the portion of speech that ha- have high energy are not ch-|
a lot affected by the noises in the Aurora database. If - if you compare|
th- the two  shut  channels of SpeechDat-Car during speech portion, it's n-|
the M_F_C_C are not very different.|
They are very different when energy's lower, like during fricatives or during speech pauses.|
Yeah, but you're still getting more recognition errors, which means  that the differences, even though they look like they're not so big,|vs: breath|
are - are hurting your recognition. Right?|
Yeah. So it distort  the speech. Right. Um.|vs: outbreath|
Yeah. So, but in this case I - I really expect that maybe|
the - the two - these two stream of features, they are very different. I mean, and|
maybe we could gain something by combining them or -|vs: outbreath|
Well, the other thing is that you just picked one particular way of doing it. Uh, I mean, first place it's fifteen D_B, uh,|vs: breath|
down across the utterance. And|vs: breath|
maybe you'd want to have something that was a little more adaptive. Secondly, you happened to pick fifteen D_B and|
maybe twenty'd be better, or - or twelve.|
So what was the - what was the threshold part of it? Was the threshold, uh, how far down - ?|
Yeah. Well, he - yeah, he had to figure out how much to add.|
So he was looking - he was looking at the peak value.|
And - and so what's - ho- I don't understand. How does it go? If it - if - if the peak value's above some threshold, then you add the noise? Or if it's below s-|
I  systematically    add the noise, but|
the, um, noise level is just  some kind of threshold below the peak.|
Oh, oh. I see. I see.|vs: inbreath|
Yeah. Which is not really  noise,  actually. It's just adding a constant to each of the mel, uh, energy.|
To each of the  mel filter bank. Yeah.|
So, yeah, it's really, uh, white noise.  I th-|
So then afterwards a log is taken, and that's|
the little variation tends to go away.|
Yeah. So may- Well, the - this threshold is still a factor that we have to look at. And|vs: mouth|
I don't know, maybe a constant noise addition would -  would be fine also, or -|vs: outbreath|
Or - or not constant but - but, uh, varying over time  in fact|vs: mouth|
Were you using the - the normalization in addition to this? I mean, what was the rest of the|vs: inbreath|
Yeah. It was - it was, uh, the same system.|
A third thing is that, um,|vs: outbreath|
I play a little bit with the, um -  finding what was different between,|vs: outbreath|
And there were a couple of differences, like the L_D_A filters were not the same.|
he had the France Telecom  blind  equalization in the system.|vs: mouth|
the number o- of M_F_C_C that was - were used was different. You used thirteen and we used fifteen.|
Well, a bunch of differences. And, um, actually|
the result that he - he got were much better on T_I-digits especially.|
So I'm kind of investigated to see what|
was the main factor for this difference. And it seems that|
the L_D_A filter is - is - was hurting.|
Um,  so when we put s- some noise compensation|vs: mouth|
the, um, L_D_A filter that - that's derived from noisy speech is not more - anymore optimal.|
And it makes a big difference, um,  on T_I-digits|vs: outbreath|
Uh, if we use the - the old L_D_A filter, I mean the L_D_A filter that was in the proposal, we have, like, eighty-two point seven percent recognition rate,|
on noisy speech when the system is trained on clean speech.|
and when we use the filter that's derived from clean speech we jumped -|
so from eighty-two point seven to eighty-five point one,|
Yeah. So now the results are more similar, and|
I don't - I will not, I think, investigate on the other differences,|
which is like the number of M_F_C_C that we keep and other small things|
that we can I think optimize later on anyway.|
Sure. But on the other hand if everybody is trying different kinds of noise suppression things and so forth, it might be good to standardize on the piece|
that we're  not  changing. Right? So if there's|
any particular reason to ha- pick one or the other, I mean -|
Which - which one is closer to what the proposal was that was submitted to Aurora? Are they -|

it have less of - of France Telecom stuff, I -|
The -  whatever  you, uh, tested with recently. Right?|
Yeah, you're trying to add in France Telecom. Tell  them   about the rest of it. Like you said the number of filters might be|
The number of cepstral coefficients is what?|
Yeah. So, I mean, I think we'd wanna standardize there, wouldn't we?|
So, sh- you guys should pick something and -|
Well, all th- all three of you.|
I think we were gonna work with - with this or this new system, or with -|
Uh, so the - the - right now, the - the system that is there in the -|
what we have in the repositories, with - uses fifteen.|
But we will use the - the L_D_A filters f- derived from clean speech.|
Well, yeah, actually it's - it's not the - the L_D_A filter. It's|
something that's also short enough in - in latency. So.|
So, we haven't - w- we have been always using, uh, fifteen coefficients, not thirteen? Yeah.|
I think as long as you guys agree on it, it doesn't matter. I think we have a maximum of sixty,|
uh, features that we're allowed. So.|vs: laugh|
Yeah. Ma- maybe we can - I mean, at least,|
um, I'll t- s- run some experiments to see whether - once I have this|
noise compensation to see whether thirteen and fifteen really matters or not.|vs: 3 tongue taps|
Never tested it with the compensation, but  without,|vs: breath|
uh, compensation it was like fifteen was s- slightly better than thirteen, so that's why we stuck to thirteen.|vs: breath|
Yeah. And there is - there is also this log energy versus C_zero.|
Yeah, the log energy versus C_zero.|
Uh, that's - that's the other thing. I mean, without noise compensation certainly C_zero is better than log energy.|
Be- I mean, because the - there are more, uh, mismatched conditions than the matching conditions for testing.|
You know, always for the  matched  condition, you always get a   slightly  better performance for log energy than C_zero.|
for matched and the clean condition both, you get log energy -|
I mean  you get a  better  performance with log energy.|
Well, um, maybe once we have this noise compensation, I don't know, we have to try that also, whether we want to go for C_zero or log energy.|
So do you have  more, Stephane, or - ?|
Uh, that's it, I think.  Mmm.|vs: mouth|vs: breath-laugh|vs: outbreath|
Do you have anything, Morgan, or - ?|vs: laugh|

that these phones are  not  voicing.|

in terms of, like, which - which, um - which of these categories are - are good for, um, speech recognition.|

So do you just take the probabilities of the other ones and spread them out evenly among the -|

That will be really interesting to see, you know.|

Oh, so then you'll feed those -|

So, like, this is from a stop to - to a vo- a vocalic|
segment. You know, so- something that is transitional in nature.|

So, um,  I guess I'll just pass it on to Dave.|vs: mouth|
Uh, O_K. Well, in my lunch talk last week I - I said I'd tried phase normalization and gotten garbage results using that l- um, long-term mean subtraction approach.|
It turned out there was a bug in my Matlab code.|
So I tried it again, um,|vs: inbreath|
were - were better. I got intelligible speech back. But they still weren't as good as just subtracting the magnitude - the log magnitude means.|
And also I've been talking to, um,|

um, far mike use of the SmartKom system. So|

one of the experiments we're gonna do is, um, we're gonna, um, train the - a Broadcast News net,|

So - but, you know, uh, you can get -|

um, you can scale it down by -|
I'm sorry, it was two, three weeks for training up for the large Broadcast News test set - training set.|
I don't know how much you'd be training on.|
The full? Uh, i- so if you trained on half as much  and made the net, uh, uh, half as big, then it would be one fourth  the amount of time and it'd be nearly as good.|vs: breath|

other ways of taking care of the phase.|

and not - not, uh, doing the polar representation with magnitude and phase. But|
it looks like there's ways that one could potentially just work with the complex numbers and - and - and in principle get rid of the|vs: breath|
effects of the average complex spectrum.|
actually, regarding the phase normalization - So I did two experiments, and one is -|
So, phases get added, modulo two pi,|
and - because you only know the phase of the complex number t- t- to a value modulo two pi. And so I thought at first, um,|
that, uh, what I should do is  unwrap  the phase because that will  undo  that.|vs: breath|
Um, but I actually got worse results doing that unwrapping using the simple phase unwrapper that's in Matlab than I did not unwrapping at all.|
And that's all I have to say.|
Yeah. So I'm - I'm still hopeful that - that - I mean, we - we don't even know if the phase|vs: mouth|
is something - the average phase is something that we  do  want to remove. I mean, maybe there's some|
deeper reason why it isn't the right thing to do. But, um,|
at least in principle it looks like there's - there's, uh, a couple potential ways to do it. One - one being to just work with the complex numbers,|
and, uh - in rectangular kind of coordinates. And the other is|
to, uh, do a Taylor series -|
Well. So you work with the complex numbers|
and then when you get the spectrum - the average complex spectrum -|
um, as opposed to taking the log and subtracting.|
um, you know, there might be some numerical issues. We don't really know that.|
The other thing we talked a little bit about was Taylor series expansion.|

so one thing is that y- you'd have to do, I think, uh -|
we may have to do this on a whiteboard, but I think you have to be a little careful about scaling the numbers that you're|

the Taylor expansion for it has, you know, a square and a cube, and - and so forth. And - and so if -|
if you have a - a number that is modulus, you know, uh, very different from one -|
It should be right around  one,  if it's -|
cuz it's a expansion of log one - one minus epsilon or o- is - is|
or is it one plus - ?  Well, there's an epsilon squared over two and an epsilon cubed over three, and so forth. So if epsilon is bigger than one, then it diverges.|

of K_ times a complex number, then you can just - that's the same as log of K_ plus  log of the complex number.|vs: breath|
